You have selected the \"Casual\" option. In this mode you have access to move takeback, Hint, Analyse, the Tutor, White Handicaps, \"Show CPU Thinking\" and \"Show Pieces in Danger\" to help you improve your game.
When selected, the CPU player is allowed to offer to resign or draw matches.

OUR CHESS PROGRAM:"
Our Chess program is based on our Treebeard chess engine, which you can read about on http://www.aifactory.co.uk/newsletter/2005_02_treebeard_chess.htm and that has been licensed for use by Microsoft in their products. This chess engine uses techniques not found in most chess programs, which allows it to play with a more human style. Unlike conventional programs, it does not search millions of positions but instead uses a probability directed search to examine less positions in more detail. This program shares its technology with the Japanese Chess program \"Shotest\", twice ranked 3rd in the world.
"

"(Current player has no legal move and isn't in check)"

ELO rating system:"
The game in \"Pro\" mode will calculate an ELO rating for you, after you have played 5 games. Note that this is based on the FIDE version of ELO and will give a good ELO rating within the app. Each CPU difficulty level in the game has a tested rating. We have set CPU Level 12 at FIDE ELO 2100 (but it might be higher), with Level 1 at 750.
However note that this will not exactly match with the ELO used in human tournaments, for the following reasons:
1. FIDE ELO and USCF would normally calculate ELO ratings from controlled timed events, but Chess Free has a more relaxed control that allows the user to take as long as they like. So the rating you receive might be higher than a human tournament rating.
2. Computer ELO does not always match up well with human ELO, so that some players may find a program is stronger than it claims whereas others will feel it is much weaker. This is because of the computer style. Humans that often play Chess programs will find quirks in the AI that they can exploit to get better results.
3. FIDE, USCF and other ELO scales differ in standard, so that, for example, USCF may differ by some 100 ELO points from FIDE.
4. There will be some variation in strength between devices. For the lower levels this will be the same on any handset, but for a fraction of moves on the higher levels a fast device will play better.
This ELO system accurately follows FIDE ELO rating changes within the app, so you will be able to track the relative change in your strength. This will allow you to develop as a player and have an idea of how well you are doing.
(Note: The \"Casual\" mode scoring system is not ELO but a simpler cumulative scoring system based on your results against all levels.)"
The last move played by the CPU was called \"En Passant\". Read the rules section for more on this.

Sign in with Google to share your progress and achievements with your friends
You are signed in with Google
You have switched on a White Handicap. This will remove the chosen piece from the White side, giving Black an advantage.

"The game of Chess is a battle between two players, who take it in turns to move their pieces, white and black. Pieces are moved either to an empty square or to a square occupied by an opponent piece which is then captured and removed from the board. The ultimate object of the game is to checkmate the opponent’s King so that it cannot escape, but this is preceded by careful manoeuvring of pieces designed to control space and gain material, and so strengthen the final attack.
Traditionally the pieces in Chess represent aspects of medieval society. The following sections describe how these pieces move."

"The 8 Pawns symbolise labourers or soldiers. They move in a forward direction, one square at a time. On its first move the Pawn can also optionally move forward two squares. These forward moves cannot be capture moves. Instead Pawns capture pieces in a forward-diagonal direction, but cannot otherwise move this way. When a Pawn reaches the other end of the board it can be changed for any other piece of its own colour, except the King of course. This is called promotion. Normally a Pawn is promoted to a Queen.
The Pawn has one extra move: the en-passant rule. This states that a double Pawn move can be immediately captured by an opponent's Pawn, if that Pawn is adjacent to the double Pawn move after the move (on its 5th rank). In practice this means that the opponent can play the normal capture that would have been available if the Pawn had only advanced one square. On the board the en-passant capture moves the capturing Pawn behind the double-move Pawn, and then removes it."

The Knight’s motion is unusual: it does not move in a straight line, but makes a double move, with a single straight and single diagonal move. This L-shaped move can be in any direction, giving 8 possible moves when the Knight is near the centre of the board. Similar to a real horse, Knights can jump over Chess pieces of the same or opposite colour. If the Knight starts off on a light square, it will finish its move on a dark square.
The Bishop can move any number of squares in a diagonal direction. It cannot jump pieces as the Knight can.
The Rook can move any number of squares in a horizontal or vertical direction. It cannot jump pieces as the Knight can.

The Queen has the ability to move in a horizontal, vertical or diagonal path across any number of spaces as long as she is not blocked. The Queen therefore combines the moves of the Rook and Bishop. The Queen is a formidable piece, and will often be central in attacks.

"The King is the main object of your opponent's attacks. Once checkmated, the game is over! It can move in all possible eight diagonal and horizontal directions, but only one square at a time. The King also has a special Castling move, where it can move two squares to left or right, with the Rook jumping over it to occupy the square on the other side of the King."

"This is only legal if the King and Rook have not moved previously, none of the squares between the Rook and King are blocked, the king is not in check and none of the squares the King passes through are attacked by enemy pieces. The King needs to be protected, but can also become a powerful attacking piece. In the end game it will offer a formidable attacking piece against enemy Pawns. In simple mating endgames, it will form part of the mating attack.
When the King is being attacked directly by an opponent's piece, we say that the King is in check. If the King is in check it must be made safe immediately.
There are 3 ways to get out of check:
1. The King may move to a square that is not being attacked by an enemy piece.
2. The piece that is attacking the King can be captured.
3. A piece may be moved between the King and the enemy piece to block the check.
If the King is in check and cannot get out, then we say the King is checkmated and the game is lost."

"(Scroll down for Chess rules)
Before starting a game, you will be presented with a Match Settings screen. From here you can choose the side to play as (or have it alternate each game), the CPU difficulty (1 for beginners, and 12 for experts), the white handicap (a white piece removed to aid black), and the game timer parameters.
There are two elements to the timers:
GAME TIMER determines the initial amount of time given to each player before the match. This counts down whilst a player is thinking about their moves, and they will instantly lose the match if it reaches zero.
MOVE TIMER is the bonus time given to a player after making a move.
Once a game has started, use the touch-screen or the dpad/joystick on the phone to select and move pieces. A piece is moved by first selecting it, then selecting a legal square to move to.
The Undo button can be used to take back as many moves as you want.
Player names, timers, taken pieces and CHECK notifications are displayed above and below the board. When the CPU is thinking about a move, an animation will play in the top right. Note that the higher the CPU difficulty, the longer the thinking times will be. If timers are active, the CPU will cut short its thinking if necessary.
During play, you can press the phone's MENU button to get access to two useful features. HINT will tell the CPU to assess your current situation and suggest a move. REVIEW GAME will take you to another screen with a moves list where you'll be able to view all moves played up to that point. The moves list is scrollable, and selecting a move will jump to that point. You can also use the navigation buttons on the left to cycle through moves one at a time, or jump to the start and end of the move history.
SAVE & QUIT is always available under the MENU button - this will save any progress or settings changes you've made, and then exit.
"STATISTICS:"
The game will track your wins/losses/draws against each of the CPU levels. This information can be accessed from the title menu screen. The rating shown in the bottom left of the stats page is a cumulative rating calculated from all your games (This is not an ELO rating.) Win percentage counts 1 point for win and 0.5 points for draw. Note that Handicap games will not count towards these statistics.
"TUTOR (from Match Settings or Options):"
Chess now has an optional tutor to help choose your move. When turned on, this automatically recommends a piece that you could move, but not where you should move it to. It therefore assists in your choice, but does not offer an exact move, so you are \"helped\" in your selection but still obliged to consider the move. Of course you can still choose HINT (?) or even ANALYSE from the MENU for exact recommendations.
This partial advice approach can help you avoid simple mistakes while also giving a nudge of how to proceed in the position.
Note, you don't have to accept the tutor's recommendation: it is simply a \"good\" choice but a better move may be available.
You can also change the tutor level in options screen. By default the program picks a tutor level to match your opponent CPU difficulty, so that it gives advice quickly but takes longer for higher levels. However you may want the tutor to think for longer to give you deeper help. You can set this to levels between 1 and 8, where 8 takes a particularly long time. Note that you can always interrupt the tutor at any time by touching the screen, after which the tutor will offer its advice immediately.
"SHOW PIECES IN DANGER (from Options):"
You can choose to \"Show Pieces In Danger\", so that the program will place a red highlight behind pieces that can be safely captured by the opponent. This can also help you learn to avoid mistakes.
"OUR CHESS PROGRAM:"
Our Chess program is based on our Treebeard chess engine, which you can read about on http://www.aifactory.co.uk/newsletter/2005_02_treebeard_chess.htm and that has been licensed for use by Microsoft in their products. This chess engine uses techniques not found in most chess programs, which allows it to play with a more human style. Unlike conventional programs, it does not search millions of positions but instead uses a probability directed search to examine less positions in more detail. This program shares its technology with the Japanese Chess program \"Shotest\", twice ranked 3rd in the world.
"HEYZAP:"
This game now supports the Heyzap games network, which allows you to optionally log to twitter or facebook when you win games. Heyzap allows you to see what games your friends are playing and for you to log achievements (badges) and share tips.
"

To save or export to PGN first, press cancel and go to menu."

"New Feature:
You can now choose how pieces are displayed on the board during Two Player games. Four different modes are available in the options. "

\"Show Pieces In Danger\" will place a red highlight behind pieces that can be safely captured by the opponent. This can help you learn to avoid mistakes.

"You have just selected Practice \"P\" difficulty.
This level is intended for Chess beginners who want to learn how to play. The CPU will play a weak game, and your stats will not be affected."
You have selected the \"Pro\" option. In this mode, all player aids are disabled, you cannot abandon a match without resigning, and stats are logged separately.
Please select a piece to promote to:
You are currently in \"Pro\" mode, which disables all player aids (like Undo). Pro matches are also logged separately in stats and cannot be abandoned.
In Casual Mode, this is a cumulative score based on your performance against all difficulty levels.

In Pro Mode, your rating is an ELO rating based on the FIDE system (after you have played 5 Pro games). Note it may differ from actual FIDE human ratings. Please read the section at the end of \"Rules of Chess\" for a full description of this.
You are now temporarily leaving the game to send a recommendation using your preferred messaging application.
Are you sure you wish to reset your stats?
"Are you sure you wish to reset all stats (Casual and Pro)? This will also reset stats on the cloud, and will reset your leaderboard progress, if you're using \"Google Play Games\" features."
"Are you sure you wish to resign this game?"
I would like to resign. Do you want to continue the game?
From this screen you can assess the current game from start to finish. Clicking on a move in the list will take you to that point in the game, or you can use the arrow buttons to navigate.

"Game successfully saved…
These can be loaded from the Main Menu."

This may drain your battery more than usual."

\"Show CPU Thinking\" will highlight the move that the CPU currently considers best, whilst it thinks. This provides insight into the CPU analysis of the current position.
"This feature needs you to be signed into Google before it'll work. When signed in, you can share your progress and achievements with your friends!"
Are you sure you wish to leave this match? You will lose all unsaved progress.
Stats have already been logged for this match, so this game will not count towards your stats when completed.
Are you sure you want to switch sides? You will take control of your opponents pieces, and they will control yours, but the game position will remain unchanged.
"Stats will not be logged for the game, and it won't count towards Achievements or Leaderboards."
Tap game to download for Free!
\"Game Timer\" is the total time you have to make all your moves. \"Move Timer\" is a time bonus added after each move you make.

The tutor helps you learn by suggesting a piece you could move. This will guide you to how to play the position and also help you avoid mistakes. You may choose to play a different piece than the one recommended.
"The Tutor Level determines how long the Tutor will think for, and therefore the strength of its moves. \"Auto\" will choose a level based on the CPU difficulty you're playing against."
This option allows you to choose how pieces are displayed in a two player game.

"Tip
Use the \"Undo\" button to deselect a chosen piece, as well as rewind the game."
Are you sure you wish to offer a draw to your opponent?

Also, if the application is not yet published, check that the account you are trying to sign in with is listed as a tester account. See logs for more information.

The ELO given here is just a reasonable guideline. CPU ELO ratings do not uniformly match human ELO ratings as computers are better than humans at some parts of the game and weaker at others. ELO for timed games may be impacted by device speed. (See end of \"Rules of Chess\" for more detail)

"The ELO given here is just a reasonable guideline. CPU ELO ratings do not uniformly match human ELO ratings as computers are better than humans at some parts of the game and weaker at others. ELO for timed games may be impacted by device speed. (See end of \"Rules of Chess\" for more detail)
NOTE: although ELO is given here, the player rating system in casual mode is not ELO, but a legacy casual rating system."
